Graphical abstract High-throughput screening for high-performance MXene-based single atom catalysts for oxygen evolution reaction was performed through first-principles calculations and machine learning techniques. Two-dimensional transition metal carbides (MXenes) have been demonstrated to be promising supports for single-atom catalysts (SACs) to enable efficient oxygen evolution reaction (OER). However, the rational design of MXene-based SACs depends on an experimental trial-and-error approach. A theoretical guidance principle is highly expected for the efficient evaluation of MXene-based SACs. Herein, high-throughput screening was performed through first-principles calculations and machine learning techniques. Ti3C2(OH) x , V3C2(OH) x , Zr3C2(OH) x , Nb3C2(OH) x , Hf3C2(OH) x , Ta3C2(OH) x , and W3C2(OH) x were screened out based on their excellent stability. Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg were proposed to be promising single atoms anchored in MXenes based on cohesive energy analysis. Hf3C2(OH) x with a Pd single atom delivers a theoretical overpotential of 81 mV. Both moderate electron-deficient state and high covalency of metal–carbon bonds were critical features for the high OER reactivity. This principle is expected to be a promising approach to the rational design of OER catalysts for metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and other OER-based energy storage devices. Keywords MXene Single-atom catalysis Oxygen evolution reaction High-throughput calculation Machine learning 1 Introduction Oxygen evolution reaction (OER) is a fundamental electrochemical process that is crucial in various technological applications, e.g., fuel cells and metal-air batteries [1]. It involves the oxidation of a water molecule to oxygen gas through a series of elementary reactions. The OER kinetics is typically sluggish due to the four-electron transfer proton-coupled process [2–5]. Electrocatalysts are urgently requested for practical applications to enhance reaction rates and efficiencies. Tremendous efforts have been dedicated to designing catalyst materials, including precious metals [6] and non-precious metals [7–9], to overcome the limitations associated with routine catalysts. However, it is urgent to rationally design OER catalysts with high activity and stability [10]. The past decade has witnessed a rapid development of two-dimensional transition metal carbides (MXenes) [11,12]. MXenes are usually synthesized by selectively etching the “A” layers from MAX phases [13]. The as-prepared layered structures exhibit large specific surface areas, metallic electrical conductivities, and high electrochemical activities [14,15], which have been widely employed in energy storage [16–20], catalysis [21–25], and sensing [26,27]. Their chemical diversity makes MXenes a versatile platform for efficient and selective catalysis [28,29], e.g., hydrogen evolution reaction [30,31], oxygen reduction reaction [32], and carbon dioxide reduction reaction [33–35]. Although remarkable achievements have been made for MXenes in the field of electrocatalysis, their performance for OER is not fully satisfactory. F-terminated MXenes exhibit low OER activity and stability because of the harsh operation conditions for OER. The intrinsic properties of MXenes motivate its application in catalyst support [36], especially in the support of single-atom catalysts (SACs) [37,38]. The large surface areas and metallic electrical conductivities of MXenes ensure the activity of single-atom sites. The electronegative surface terminations of MXenes are conducive to the adsorption and anchoring of metal cations. The defect sites with unsaturated coordination produced during the preparation process can reduce metal cations simultaneously [39,40]. These characteristics endow MXenes with enormous potential as supports of SACs. Co@V2CT x delivers an OER overpotential of 242 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte, comparable to the commercial noble Pt/C and RuO2/C electrocatalysts [41]. This result exhibits the great prospect of MXene-based SACs in efficient OER. Kan et al. predicted the OER properties of 26 MXenes with Pt single atoms through first-principles calculations. Nb2CF2, Nb4C3F2, and Cr2TiC2F2 were proposed to be promising OER catalysts [42]. However, plentiful MXene-based SACs for OER are still buried now. In this contribution, a comprehensive theoretical evaluation of MXene-based SACs was performed through high-throughput first-principles calculations (Fig. 1 ). The vacancy in the M layer of MXenes is considered as a single atom site, which has been experimentally demonstrated in previous work [37,38]. Firstly, the stability of MXenes was evaluated based on specific formation energies. 7 possible MXene candidates including Ti3C2(OH) x , V3C2(OH) x , Zr3C2(OH) x , Nb3C2(OH) x , Hf3C2(OH) x , Ta3C2(OH) x , and W3C2(OH) x were screened out for promising single atom supports. Secondly, 29 transition metal elements were considered for possible single-atom elements. Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg single atoms were filtered based on their high cohesive energies, indicating their excellent stability. The theoretical overpotentials of these MXenes-based SACs were determined by Gibbs free energy calculations. The structure-activity relationship was further analyzed by machine learning techniques. The moderate electron-deficient single-atom center and the highly covalent M–C bond were proposed as two critical features for optimal OER activity. This principle is expected to be a promising approach to enable the rational design of OER catalysts. 2 Results and discussion Robustness is the first feature for high-performance OER catalysts since OER takes place in harsh operation conditions (e.g., strong alkaline environments and high current density water splitting). The structural stability of MXenes was evaluated based on specific formation energies. The specific formation energy is defined as the averaged (per M–C bond) energy difference between the total energies of MXenes and the atomic energies of the composed atoms. Ti3C2, V3C2, Zr3C2, Nb3C2, Hf3C2, Ta3C2, and W3C2 are predicted to be thermodynamically stable because of their negative specific formation energy of less than −3.0 eV (Fig. 2 a). These MXenes are considered as stable supports to load single atoms for OER. The relationship between the specific formation energy and the d electron counting of transition metal presents an inverted volcanic profile. The minimum value of the specific formation energy is reached at the d electron counting of 2–4, corresponding to IVB–VIB group elements. Such characteristic is attributed to the strong metal–carbon bonding induced by the octahedral coordination configuration in MXenes, in agreement with previous results [43,44]. Both IB and IIB group element-based MXenes are unstable due to the valence configuration mismatch caused by their unoccupied d orbitals and decreased bond strengths. The agglomeration of single atoms is one of the origins of SAC deactivation. The choice of elements with positive cohesive energies is a practical requirement to avoid agglomeration. The cohesive energies of transition metal single atoms were further determined. Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg were predicted to be promising elements for SACs due to their positive cohesive energy (Fig. 2b). The elements with positive cohesive energies are concentrated in IB and IIB groups. The subsequent exploration was performed based on the combination of the substrates (Ti3C2, V3C2, Zr3C2, Nb3C2, Hf3C2, Ta3C2, and W3C2) and the single atoms (Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg). The affinity for reactants determines the adsorption behavior of reactants and therefore determines the utilization of active sites concerning catalysts. A high-performance catalyst is supposed to render a high adsorption affinity for reaction agents and trigger subsequent reaction process. The affinity for the reactants is described by H2O adsorption energy for OER (Fig. 2c and d). The MXene surface was usually decorated with functional groups including –F, –O, and/or hydroxyl groups, which significantly regulates H2O adsorption energies. Herein, the F and OH terminations were selected for the surface analysis, because of the dominant distributions of the two terminations on MXene surfaces [45]. Several surface terminations were randomly added to MXene surfaces. The effect of pH on the formation energies of MXenes with F or OH terminations was determined. F termination is thermodynamically more favorable than OH termination in acidic condition, while the opposing situation appears in alkaline condition. MXenes with OH terminations were further adopted for the evaluation of theoretical overpotentials because of the commonality of alkaline conditions for OER (Figs. S1 and S2). Ti3C2 with a single atom exhibits poor affinity for H2O except that with a Hg single atom, which is attributed to the hydrophobicity of Ti3C2 [46,47]. Such characteristics are detrimental to OER and limit the activities of OER. The negative H2O adsorption energies of Hf3C2(OH) x and Nb3C2(OH) x indicate their strong affinity for H2O, conducive to the occurrence of OER. The Ag single atoms were experimentally observed to possess superior hydrophilicity [48,49], which facilitate the proximity of reactants to single atomic sites and trigger subsequent reactions. The optimal catalytic properties generally depend on moderate binding strengths according to Sabatier's principle [50]. Although the binding energies of reactants partly represent the activities of OER at initial states, they cannot fully reflect the overall catalytic properties considering the four-electron transfer proton-coupled reaction of OER [51]. The overall properties of OER including theoretical overpotential and product selectivity need to be determined by Gibbs free energy diagrams. The Gibbs free energy diagram of Ti3C2(OH) x will not be considered because of the hydrophilicity of Ti3C2. Note that the hydroxyl group can significantly regulate the H2O adsorption energy based on the comparison of adsorption energies of bare and functionalized MXenes (Fig. 2d). All subsequent calculations were performed based on the functionalized MXene models. The geometric structures of OER intermediates and the Gibbs free energy diagrams of MXenes with single atoms for OER are shown in Figs. S3–S8 and Fig. 3 , respectively. The Gibbs free energy changes of OER intermediates were listed in Tables S1–S6. The theoretical overpotentials are summarized in Fig. 4 . The predicted rate determination steps of OER are determined to be deprotonation step (*OH + OH− → *O + H2O) or O–O bond formation step (*O + OH− → *OOH), consistent with the previous report [52]. The theoretical overpotential was further obtained based on the Gibbs free energy diagrams. Au–V3C2(OH) x (298 mV), Au–Nb3C2(OH) x (302 mV), and Au–Ta3C2(OH) x (293 mV) deliver low theoretical overpotentials (Fig. 3a, c, and e), indicating their excellent catalytic activity for OER. Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x delivers a theoretical overpotential of 81 mV (Fig. 3d), comparable with that of the state-of-the-art RuO2. The Cd single atom is feasible for constructing high-performance OER catalysts for Zr3C2(OH) x (225 mV) and W3C2(OH) x (354 mV) (Fig. 4). The dynamics stability of Hg–Ta3C2(OH) x , Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x , and Ag–Hf3C2(OH) x was further validated via the ab initio molecular dynamics simulation (Fig. S9) and vibrational density of states (Fig. S10). However, the structural and electronic origin of low theoretical overpotentials of MXenes with single atoms is unclear and needs to be further understood. The electronic structure of Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x was further analyzed to understand the electronic origin of its high OER activity. The adsorption of the OH intermediate on Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x was focused because its rate determination step for OER was predicted to be the deprotonation step (*OH + OH− → *O + H2O). The abundant density of states of Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x at the Fermi level ensures its high electrical conductivity (Fig. 5 a), which is one of the perquisites of promising electrocatalysts. Such characteristic remains as the OH intermediate is adsorbed on Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x (Fig. 5b). The effects of the Pd single atom and the OH intermediate on the local charge density of Hf3C2(OH) x and Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x were revealed by charge density difference analyses, respectively. The former compares the charge density between Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x and Hf3C2(OH) x /Pd single atom, while the latter compares the charge density between Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x with an adsorbed OH and Pd–Hf3C2(OH) x /OH intermediate. The interaction between Pd single atom and Hf3C2(OH) x contributes to the delocalized distribution of Pd-d electrons (Fig. 5c and e). These delocalized d electrons are captured by the OH intermediate (Fig. 5d and f), promoting its adsorption on the Pd single atom site. The moderate interaction between the Pd single atom site and OH intermediate is the origin of its high OER activity. Machine learning methods were adopted to reveal the relationship between the geometry/electronic structures of MXenes with single atoms and OER activities. Artificial neural networks (ANN) architecture includes five layers, i.e., a feature input layer, a fully connected layer, a ReLu layer, another fully connected layer, and a regression output layer (Fig. 6 a). The 12 features including atomic numbers of single atoms, atomic radii of single atoms, atomic mass of single atoms, M–C bond order, coordination numbers of single atoms, d electron countings of single atoms, d band centers of single atoms, Pauli electronegativity of single atoms, electron affinity of single atoms, first ionization energies of single atoms, Bader charges of single atoms, and transferred charges between single atoms and MXenes were used as the input features. Adaptive weighted cross features were adopted considering possible cross effects between features. The M–C bond order and the Bader charge were identified as the critical features correlated with the theoretical overpotentials based on feature engineering, which was performed employing the maximum relevance and minimum redundancy (MRMR) method. Similar weight significances were received by support vector machine, gradient boosting decision tree, and naive Bayes classifier (Fig. S11). The descriptors involving the single atom-MXene interaction show a better fitting with the theoretical overpotentials than the single atom property descriptors (Fig. S12). The negative correlation between the theoretical overpotential and the M–C bond order indicates that the high covalency of M–C bond delivers low theoretical overpotential (Fig. 6b). The volcano-shaped correlation was observed between the theoretical overpotential and Bader charges of the single atoms (Fig. 6c), indicating that the optimal OER activity is located at the moderate electron-deficient state. The moderate electron-deficient state and high covalency of M–C bond were significant for developing high-performance OER catalysts, which would provide a guiding principle for OER catalyst design. The SACs have attracted strong attention due to their maximum atom utilization, high catalytic activity, and improved selectivity. The supports for single atom sites need to exhibit large surface area, metallic electrical conductivity, and strong bonding with single atoms, enabling the activity and stability of SACs. These material property requirements are met by MXenes [53,54], endowing them with great potential as support materials. The superior activity of Co@V2CT x has been reported, delivering an OER overpotential of 242 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH electrolyte [41]. The chemical diversity of MXenes and single atom sites provides a vast space for the property regulation of MXene-based SACs [55,56]. Compared to the traditional experimental trial-and-error method, the rational design of materials with the help of high-throughput calculations and big data methods is expected to rapidly search promising candidates from the composition space, which can significantly improve the efficiency and reduce the cost of research and development [41,57–61]. The predicted Hf3C2(OH) x with a Pd single atom delivers a theoretical overpotential of 81 mV, comparable with that of the state-of-the-art RuO2, which presents the application prospect of MXene-based SACs. Despite the fact that the oxidation of MXenes at high potential might affect the OER activity, surface doping [62] and anion intercalation [63] were demonstrated to be promising approaches to enhance the stability of MXenes. These strategies are helpful to increase the possibility of MXene-based single atom catalysts in the application of OER. The correlation between the M–C bond order/the Bader charge and the OER activity was revealed through the data-driven model, which was screened from 12 features including atomic number, atomic radius, atomic mass of transition metal, M–C bond length, coordination number, d electron counting, d band center, Pauli electronegativity, electron affinity, first ionization energy, Bader charge, and transferred charge. This relationship indicates that the MXene-based SACs with moderate single atom–support interactions are supposed to exhibit superior OER activities, which is expected to theoretically guide the design of SACs [64–70]. Data-driven approaches provide the estimations of surface activities accurately and efficiently, which are increasingly involved in the rational design of catalysts [71,72]. Fe-N-C dispersed NiFeCe layered double hydroxide (FeNC@LDH) oxygen electrocatalyst was proposed based on the data-driven analyses of 247 reported bifunctional electrocatalysts, which delivered a remarkable electrocatalytic activity with ΔE of 0.57 V [73]. Active and stable binary alloys were screened efficiently for industrial catalytic conversion of single-carbon molecules, which was performed based on a data-driven approach with fully interpretable physical features [74]. These advances demonstrate the great potential of data-driven approaches to catalyst design, enabling the development of new catalysts [66,75–77]. 3 Conclusions A rational design principle with moderate electron-deficient state and high covalency of metal–carbon bond is proposed to hunt for active MXenes-based SACs for OER through high-throughput calculations and machine learning techniques. Ti3C2(OH) x , V3C2(OH) x , Zr3C2(OH) x , Nb3C2(OH) x , Hf3C2(OH) x , Ta3C2(OH) x , and W3C2(OH) x were screened out based on their excellent stability. Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg are proposed to be promising single atoms anchored in MXenes based on cohesive energy analysis. Hf3C2(OH) x with a Pd single atom delivers a theoretical overpotential of 81 mV. The data predicted from M3C2-based MXenes is expected to be effective for other MXene family containing M2X-, M4X3-, and M5X4-type carbides, nitrides, and carbonitrides. Similar structural topologies in different types of MXenes might ensure the generalization of data-driven models, enabling efficient model transfer. Therefore, the proposed principle is highly expected to be a promising approach to search for OER catalysts for the practical application of efficient and rechargeable metal-air batteries, regenerative fuel cells, and other rechargeable OER-based energy storage devices. coredata.dc:description: Two-dimensional transition metal carbides (MXenes) have been demonstrated to be promising supports for single-atom catalysts (SACs) to enable efficient oxygen evolution reaction (OER). However, the rational design of MXene-based SACs depends on an experimental trial-and-error approach. A theoretical guidance principle is highly expected for the efficient evaluation of MXene-based SACs. Herein, high-throughput screening was performed through first-principles calculations and machine learning techniques. Ti3C2(OH) x , V3C2(OH) x , Zr3C2(OH) x , Nb3C2(OH) x , Hf3C2(OH) x , Ta3C2(OH) x , and W3C2(OH) x were screened out based on their excellent stability. Zn, Pd, Ag, Cd, Au, and Hg were proposed to be promising single atoms anchored in MXenes based on cohesive energy analysis. Hf3C2(OH) x with a Pd single atom delivers a theoretical overpotential of 81 mV. Both moderate electron-deficient state and high covalency of metal–carbon bonds were critical features for the high OER reactivity. This principle is expected to be a promising approach to the rational design of OER catalysts for metal-air batteries, fuel cells, and other OER-based energy storage devices.
